ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF CHINA
(Reappraisal of relations)


    1. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour, in view of the rapid changes taking place in Southeast Asia, if he will consider a more realistic reappraisal of relations with the People's Republic of China.

    The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, though I agree with the hon. Member that rapid changes are taking place in Southeast Asia, there appears to be no change as yet on the part of the People's Republic of China towards the Republic of Singapore. Members of the House are no doubt aware that the policy of the People's Republic of China towards Singapore is that it does not exist as an independent state and that it is, as far as it is concerned, a part of what the Chinese Government refers to as Malaya.

    This being so, I do not see how Singapore could consider a "more realistic reappraisal of relations" with a country which, for reasons of its own, considers that the State of Singapore does not exist.

    However, the policy of the Singapore Government has been, as has constantly

Column: 168

been reiterated, to be friendly with all governments which are ready to be friendly with it. But it is extremely difficult to be friendly with a government which appears to believe that the State of Singapore does not exist.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan (Crawford)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker. Sir, I have two supplementary questions to raise.

    First, the Minister for Foreign Affairs has said that basically the attitude of the People's Republic of China towards us has not changed. But if we continue to do things like letting the Taiwan Government's trade representatives conduct their business in Singapore, how can we expect the People's Republic of China to change its attitude towards us?

    Second, what kind of attitude will our representatives in the United Nations adopt towards the question of admission of the People's Republic of China?

    Mr Rajaratnam: I think the Member is aware that in regard to trade between countries, the question of recognition does not enter into the picture. We do trade with the People's Republic of China despite the fact that it does not recognise us. Similarly we do trade with the Taiwan Government despite the fact that it does recognise our existence. So I think trade has nothing to do with the question of recognition.

Column: 169



    In regard to our attitude towards the People's Republic of China in the United Nations, if the Member will read the back numbers of newspapers, he will see that we have made our position clear -that we are for the admission of China to the United Nations. But, unfortunately, in the United Nations this question is not decided on its merits. There is a lot of political manoeuvring going on. So the questions are invariably phrased in such a way as to compel us to take sides on what are essentially big power political struggles in the United Nations. So we always say that in principle we are quite prepared to support, as we have, the admission of China to the United Nations. Once having decided on that, we shall consider the question of the status of Formosa.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, a further supplementary question. The Foreign Minister has said that trade and diplomatic recognition are two separate matters. But I would like to know this. We have trade contacts with the Taiwan Government in the five years since we became independent. But have we any trade contacts officially with the People's Republic of China?

    The second point I would like the Foreign Minister to clarify is this. In the United Nations, do we adopt the attitude that, as a tactical measure, we avoid facing the important question of recognition of the People's Republic of China's right of representation? If we do, I cannot agree with this attitude.

    Mr Rajaratnam: In regard to trade again, if the Member will go around Singapore, I think he will find that a lot of trade is going on with China. He can buy goods from China. I think we have a perfect understanding on that score. Even American tourists come here and buy cheap goods from China.

    In regard to our stand in the United Nations, as I have already said, we are for the admission of the People's Republic of China to the United

Column: 170

Nations. There are some 140 nations who have different views, and therefore this question has never really been decided on a straightforward yes or no.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan(In Mandarin): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to make a clear-cut statement in this connection. Since we recognise the People's Republic of China as the only logical representative of China in the United Nations, is he of the view that the People's Republic of China is the only government which can represent the Chinese people in the United Nations? Maybe as the Minister for Foreign Affairs he finds it very difficult to make a clear-cut statement, but I would like to ask him to do so.

    The second question is this: since our independence, have we established any official trade links, directly or indirectly, with the People's Republic of China?

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think no Foreign Minister ever gives any direct answers to questions which are not necessarily in the interest of Singapore. The Member will agree that any answer that I give should not be in the interest of the People's Republic of China, but in the interest of the people of the Republic of Singapore. So my answer is that we recognise that the seat now occupied by the representative of Nationalist China should be occupied by the representative of the People's Republic of China. As to who really represents the people of China, I have never been there; I have never consulted the 700 million people of China. So it is not for me to say, and it is not for the Member to say.

    In regard to trade links, we have lots of trade links. Goods are coming here from China. They have a bank here. I think that is concrete evidence that whatever the theory might be, in practice there are considerable trade relations which, may I add, are by and large to the advantage of the People's Republic of China. They sell to us more than they buy from us, which is not a bad situation to be in for even the People's Republic of China.

CENTRAL PROVIDENT
FUND DEPOSITS
(Payment of property tax on Housing Board flats)


    2. Mr Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Minister for Labour if he will consider introducing amending legislation to allow owner-occupiers of Housing and Development Board flats who are unemployed or in straitened circumstances to utilise their Central Provident Fund deposits for the payment of property tax on their flats.

    Mr S. Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, owner-occupiers of Housing and Development Board flats are already favourably treated in that they are allowed to use their Central Provident Fund deposits towards an initial down payment and monthly instalments on their flats. It would defeat the essential purpose of the Central Provident Fund - which is savings - were this advantage to be extended further to enable contributors to use their C.P.F, deposits towards payment of property tax. To allow them to withdraw money for this purpose would be conceding to Housing and Development Board flat owners an advantage not enjoyed by other property owners who may be equally hard pressed in regard to payment of property tax.

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Mr Speaker, Sir, my question is framed in such a way that I am asking whether this facility can be extended only to owner-occupiers who are unemployed or in straitened circumstances. I agree with the Minister that it should not be done for all owner-occupiers. In my meet-the-people sessions, I have come across people who had utilised their C.P.F, deposits to purchase a Housing Board flat and, after a year or so, they found themselves out of a job, and because of age and other circumstances, they were unable to obtain any alternative employment and so were in no position to pay the property tax.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, I repeat that the principle of the Central

Column: 172

Provident Fund is saving. Buying a house is another way of saving - providing for yourself. But to allow the C.P.F, deposits to be used either to pay property tax or to sustain yourself conflicts with the principle of the C.P.F.

Column: 172

IRON RAILINGS ON
ROAD-DIVIDERS
(Measures to discourage use by pedestrians)


    3. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will consider measures to discourage pedestrians from climbing over the iron railings erected on road-dividers wherever a pedestrian overhead bridge nearby has been provided for crossing a road.

    The Acting Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are at present 23 pedestrian overhead bridges in the Republic. In order to encourage pedestrians to use the bridges when crossing the roads, iron railings have been erected on road-dividers under ten of these bridges, and the P.W.D, has plans in hand to erect railings under the remaining bridges. Besides erecting these fence-type obstacles to discourage persons from crossing the road at random, police personnel are posted at overhead bridges, especially during the road safety campaigns, to persuade pedestrians to make use of the bridges.

    There are no provisions in the law at present to enable the police to take action against persons who cross a road where an overhead bridge has been constructed. We may have to consider a law for the control of jay-walkers.

DISCIPLINARY PROCEEDINGS
AGAINST TEACHERS
(Prior consultation with teachers' union)


    4. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education whether it is the present practice of his Ministry to consult the union of a teacher before disciplinary proceedings with a view to dismissal are instituted against him, and, if not, whether consideration will be given to adopting this practice.

Column: 173



    The Minister for Education (Mr Ong Pang Boon): Mr Speaker, Sir, disciplinary proceedings with a view to dismissal are regulated by the Public Service (Disciplinary Proceedings) Regulations in the case of teachers in Government schools and by the Schools Regulations and Grant-in-Aid Regulations under the Education Ordinance in the case of aided-school teachers.

    The Public Service Commission is the final authority for the former and the Director of Education for the latter. In both cases there is no provision for the union of a teacher to be consulted before action is taken. The extreme penalty of dismissal is not exercised lightly. It is resorted to only when the offence is severe enough to justify its imposition and when there is sufficient evidence after thorough investigation. The Ministry is of the view that the present regulations provide adequate safeguards against a miscarriage of justice, and there is no reason for changing them.

    Mr Tay Boon Too (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister say how many teachers who were sacked have been re-employed?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Sir, I do not have the figure with me, but if the Member wants it, I can supply it to him later.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I merely want to know whether there are teachers who have been re-employed after having been sacked.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, as far as I am aware, there were 11 cases of dismissals. I do not think there is any case of reinstatement.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I know of several teachers who have been reinstated in their posts after having been sacked. I can give examples. From this, we can see that the final decision rests with the Public Service Commission, and it may not always be correct. I would like to stress that the authorities concerned

Column: 174

should consult the union of the teacher before disciplinary proceedings are taken against him.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Sir, if it is a question of dismissal by the Public Service Commission, then, as far as I am aware, none of them has been reinstated.

Column: 174

GOVERNMENT-AIDED SCHOOL TEACHERS
(Payment of gratuity on retirement)


    5. Mr Tay Boon Too asked the Minister for Education if the Government will consider the payment of a gratuity to a teacher of a Government-aided school on retirement.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, aided-school teachers are members of the Central Provident Fund. The Government makes a monthly C.P.F, contribution at the rate of eight per cent of the officer's total emoluments. The rate of contribution will eventually be raised to 10 per cent.

    On retirement, the aided-school teacher receives his C.P.F, benefits instead of a gratuity and pension payable to a retired Government teacher. Aided-school teachers who leave the service prior to their retirement age are allowed to retain the Government's share of the C.P.F, contributions.

    With the recent increases in the rate of Government C.P.F, contributions to the present eight per cent (with expectation of an eventual rise to 10 per cent), aided-school teachers on retirement receive a reasonable sum of money by way of superannuation benefits, if in addition to C.P.F, contributions, a gratuity is given to aided-school teachers, their superannuation benefits will be much more than the super-annuation benefits of Government teachers.

    Mr Tay Boon Too(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Minister say why Government teachers get pension and gratuity on retirement and not Government-aided school teachers?

Column: 175



    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Sir, the difference is that one is a Government servant and the other is not. If the Member is so keen on joining Government service, there are ways and means for him to do so.

CERTIFICATES OF SUITABILITY
(Particulars, and review of policy)


    6. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Minister for Education (a) what are the figures, as, at the latest convenient date, of (i) the number of applications for Certificates of Suitability for admission to the various institutions of higher learning in the Republic; (ii) the number rejected and the reasons therefor; and (iii) the number of Certificates granted and subsequently withdrawn; and (b) whether he will carry out a complete review of the policy on the matter having regard to the students' inherent right to higher education.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, up to 24th July, 1970, a total of 13,311 applications for Certificates of Suitability had been received. Breakdown figures by institutions of higher learning are not kept, as most applicants apply for admission to more than one institution in a single application. Only seven cases out of a total of 13,311 applications, or 0.053 per cent, were rejected on security grounds. The number of certificates granted and subsequently withdrawn is nil.

    The requirement of the Certificate of Suitability under the provisions of the Internal Security Act is to ensure that institutions of higher learning are not turned into a hotbed of subversive political activities which are not conducive to the pursuit of knowledge. As explained by the Minister of Defence in a press statement issued in March 1967, the Government adopted this requirement with two objectives in mind. The first was to prevent a high concentration of Communist-indoctrinated students collecting together in a tertiary institution with the intention of not only controlling the students' activities, but also intimidating the teaching staff and in the end taking over the running of the

Column: 176

institution. The second purpose was to deter students from getting mixed up in Communist United Front activities.

    I would, however, like to make an observation on the so-called "students' inherent right to higher education". The primary consideration for admission to a higher institution of learning is the possession of academic standards acceptable to the institution concerned. This implies that not all students who seek admission can be admitted even though they may have the minimum qualifications. Furthermore, the number of students that can be admitted to an institution of higher learning depends on a number of factors, such as accommodation, staffing and finance, which in turn depend on the economy of the country and its manpower requirements. There can, therefore, be no inherent right to higher education for anybody.

    Nevertheless, the "students' inherent right to higher education" is a stirring slogan which is often used by politicians and political parties in their struggle for political power. However, once power is seized, no party ever honours it, whether it be in a western democracy or a Communist state, for the simple reason that it is only an empty, albeit catching, slogan.

    In a recent sitting of Parliament, the Member for Crawford made a pertinent point that the days of slogan shouting were over. I am afraid the so-called "students' inherent right to higher education" is precisely the type of empty and meaningless slogan shouting so deplored by the Member for Crawford.

    Mr Low Yong Nguan: Mr Speaker, Sir, before I ask my supplementary questions, I would like to point out that I do not shout empty slogans. I believe in the students' right to higher education, and I believe in what I am saying.

    I would like the Minister to clarify a few questions. Firstly, in view of so much talk about the political stability that is existing in our country, are the grounds enunciated by the Minister and on which we base the whole question of Certificates of Suitability still valid? Secondly, we have just been informed

Column: 177

by the Minister that seven applications were rejected. Although the Minister has said that breakdown figures by institutions are not kept, may I know whether the seven rejected cases were citizens or non-citizens, and can the Minister say for which institution of higher learning these cases applied? Thirdly, the Minister has made mention of the minimum qualifications for entry into an institution of higher learning. With such licensing of right to enter an institution, I wonder whether it is also one of the qualifications to be found suitable by the licensing authority, apart from the required academic qualifications?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not have the facts regarding the citizenship status of the seven cases which were rejected on security grounds. But I can supply the information to the Member for Crawford in due course.

    The grounds for the introduction of the Certificates of Suitability are still valid in spite of the political stability of our state. Maybe the relatively peaceful conditions that are prevailing in our universities is, in large measure, due to the existence of the Certificate of Suitability requirement.

PRE-UNIVERSITY CLASSES
IN MALAY SCHOOLS
(Sufficient number from 1971)


    7. Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap asked the Minister for Education if his Ministry is satisfied that the number of pre-university classes in Malay schools will be sufficient to meet the demands as from 1971.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Inche Mohd. Ghazali Bin Ismail) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, admission to our pre-university classes in all language streams is based upon the applicants' performance in the relevant public examination for Secondary 4 pupils as well as their extra-curricular activities. According to our estimates, sufficient places will be available in and

Column: 178

after 1971 for all candidates who possess the requisite qualifications for admission to pre-university classes in the Malay stream.

    Inche Rahmat Bin Kenap (Geylang Serai)(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, can the Parliamentary Secretary clarify why the pre-university classes in the Malay stream are for Arts and not for Science?

    Inche Mohd. Ghazali: Sir, no provision is made for the Science stream in pre-university Malay-medium classes because, firstly, in the early years of Malay secondary education, Malay-medium students normally offered General Science as a science subject. It was, therefore, felt that the provision of a Science stream could be considered only when the Malay stream students were able to do pure sciences up to Secondary 4 level.

    Secondly, at present the students in Secondary 3 and Secondary 4 at the Sekolah Menengah Tun Seri Lanang study their pure science subjects in English. These students can therefore be eventually channelled to the English-medium pre-university classes.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary why the Malay stream pre-university classes are only in the Sang Nila Utama Secondary School. Will the Minister also consider the setting up of Malay pre-university classes in the Ahmad Ibrahim Integrated Secondary School? This is because in the Sembawang area, there are many Malay stream students. If pre-university classes are established there, it will be convenient to all of them.

    Inche Mohd. Ghazali: Mr Speaker, Sir, to have more than one centre would mean the redeployment of staff resources concentrated at the Sang Nila Utama Secondary School to the second centre. It is considered that this would not be advisable if a high standard of performance of the pre-university students is to be achieved. Furthermore, I think to date the need to open another pre-university centre for Malay-medium students does not arise.

NATIONAL LIBRARY
(Complete air-conditioning)


    8. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Culture when the National Library will be entirely air-conditioned.

    The Minister for Culture (Mr Jek Yeun Thong): Mr Speaker, Sir, the National Library will he entirely air-conditioned when funds are made available. It is estimated that it will require about $90,000 to air-condition the remaining part of the building which is at present not air-conditioned. It is considered that at present there are more urgent library projects for which funds are needed, such as the provision of full-time branch libraries in satellite towns and the extension of the National Library's Southeast Asian Room and library stacks.

    Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): My question is, when will the National Library be entirely air-conditioned? I want to know the date. I am not worried about the funds.

    Mr Jek Yeun Thong: The date is when we have the money!

YOUTH DEPARTMENT
(Co-ordination and promotion of youth activities in Republic)


    9. Mr Low Yong Nguan asked the Minister for Social Affairs if the Government will take immediate steps to set up a Youth Department for the purpose of co-ordinating and promoting youth activities in the Republic with a view to preventing a general deterioration in the attitude of youths towards society and enhancing their appreciation of moral principles in a progressive democracy.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng) (for the Minister for Social Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, the child receives his first lesson in moral education in the home. In the school-going years, character growth will be influenced by his experience in the school and the playing field. Our educational policy seeks to develop in our school

Column: 180

children a sound ethical foundation through the inculcation of the principle of loyalty to the state, social awareness and civic consciousness. The current accent on extra-curricular activities with particular emphasis on sports promotion opens up further opportunities for character and moral development.

    When a male reaches the age of 18, he will undergo a period of national service. During his training in the Armed Forces, heavy emphasis will be laid on developing patriotism, discipline and a sense of responsibility.

    For those who do not fall within the ambit of school or national service, the People's Association organises healthy recreational activities for the population as a whole, and for youth in particular. The People's Association was established as a statutory body in 1960 to promote group participation in social, cultural, educational and physical activities. Community centres were built all over the Republic to provide facilities for these activities. Staff were sent abroad to broaden their experiences through attending training courses, work camps and conferences. In 1964, the Youth Leadership Training Centre was set up to fill a long-felt need for the training of youth leaders. In the activities organised by the People's Association, youth participation has always been encouraged with a view not only to developing their character potential, but also to fostering in them a sense of national identity and a dedicated spirit of service to the community.

    Other organisations, like the Council of Social Service, the National Youth Leadership Training Institute, the Outward Bound School, and the youth organisations affiliated to the People's Association, also cater for the promotion of youth activities and training.

    It will be seen that youth activities are being encouraged in many diverse ways by different departments in the Republic according to the various needs of youth during their successive levels of development. It would not be possible or necessary, therefore, for a single organisation

Column: 181

or department to promote youth activities in the Republic. The question of co-ordinating these activities will be looked into, if necessary.

ALEXANDRA ROAD
(Plans for safety of pedestrians)


    10. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Law and National Development (a) in view of the growing population and heavy vehicular traffic along Alexandra Road between Delta Circus and Alexandra Circus, if he has any plans to ensure the safety of pedestrians in that area; and (b) if he will consider the installation of traffic control lights at the zebra-crossing in front of the Alexandra Road Post Office as pedestrians are finding it increasingly unsafe to use that crossing.

    The Minister for Law and National Development (Mr E. W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, the safety of pedestrians using the stretch of road between Delta Circus and Alexandra Circus has been under close study for some time by our road engineers and the Road Department Committee. I am pleased to inform the Member for Delta that the Committee has decided to construct an overhead bridge to replace the zebra crossing in front of the Alexandra Road Post Office. Tenders for the construction of the overhead bridge will be called shortly, and it is expected that the bridge will be completed by the end of the year or soon thereafter.

SINGAPORE INSTITUTE OF
STANDARDS AND INDUSTRIAL
RESEARCH
(Issue of quality certificates to industries)


    11. Mr J. F. Conceicao asked the Minister for Finance how many quality certificates have been issued to various industries by the Singapore Institute of Standards and Industrial Research; and what encouragement is being given to firms to qualify for such certificates.

Column: 182



    The Minister of State for Finance (Mr Tang See Chim) (for the Minister for Finance): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Quality Certificate Scheme was initiated in August 1969 and by June this year 21 certificates had been awarded for various products.
